results.adx_keywords: your-feed-science;your-feed-health;Spine (Body Part);Paralysis;Implants;Brain;Artificial Intelligence;Nature (Journal);Lausanne (Switzerland)
results.title: A Paralyzed Man Can Walk Naturally Again With Brain and Spine Implants
results.abstract: In a new study, researchers describe a device that connects the intentions of a paralyzed patient to his physical movements.

media.caption: For more than a decade, Gert-Jan Oskam has been paralyzed from the waist down. On Wednesday, scientists described implants that provided a “digital bridge” between his brain and his spinal cord, bypassing injured sections and enabling him to walk.

results.title: Tina Turner: A Life in Photos
results.abstract: A performer who leveraged fringe, sequins and sparkles to electrifying effect onstage.

media.caption: Tina Turner performing in Brighton, England, in 1985.
media.copyright: John Rogers/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images

results.adx_keywords: Typhoons;Power Failures and Blackouts;Hurricanes and Tropical Storms;Cyclones;Disasters and Emergencies;Weather;Guam;United States
results.byline: By Josie Moyer, Mar-Vic Cagurangan, Mike Ives and Derrick Bryson Taylor
results.title: Mawar Gains Strength After Thrashing Guam, Becoming a Super Typhoon
results.abstract: Island residents experienced howling winds and periods of intense rainfall, which left most of Guam without power. Officials had yet to assess the damage, but typhoon warnings remained in effect.

results.adx_keywords: Assaults;Transit Systems;Subways;Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides;Crime and Criminals;New York City
results.title: Man Is Charged With Shoving Woman’s Head Against Moving Subway Train
results.abstract: The apparently random attack was an unsettling example of the kind of crime that has made some New Yorkers wary of the mass-transit system.

media.caption: Police officers at the Manhattan subway station where a man pushed a woman’s head into a moving train on Sunday.

results.adx_keywords: National Parks, Monuments and Seashores;Parks and Other Recreation Areas;Bison;Cattle;Animals;National Park Service;Yellowstone National Park
results.title: Bison Calf at Yellowstone Is Euthanized After Man’s Intervention
results.abstract: Park officials said they were trying to identify a man who moved the calf after it was separated from its mother and herd, causing the herd to reject it.

media.caption: The National Park Service is seeking information on a man who interacted with a newborn bison calf, which it said had to be euthanized after it was rejected by its herd.

results.title: Florida School Restricts Access to Amanda Gorman’s Inauguration Poem
results.abstract: A grade school in Miami-Dade County said “The Hill We Climb,” which Ms. Gorman read at President Biden’s inauguration in 2021, was “better suited” for older students after a parent complained about it.

results.adx_keywords: Airlines and Airplanes;Customs, Etiquette and Manners;Flight Attendants;Content Type: Service;Travel and Vacations
results.title: ‘Never a Reason to Take Off Your Socks’: A Flight Attendant’s 12 Etiquette Rules
results.abstract: Air travel is going to be busy this summer. With some common sense and courtesy, could flying be … pleasant?

media.caption: There’s plenty to grumble about when it comes to flying these days. Still, a little kindness can go a long way toward a better summer season of air travel.

results.adx_keywords: Drug Abuse and Traffic;Rap and Hip-Hop;Maxwell, Willie (Fetty Wap);Peace, Breon S;Seybert, Joanna;Central Islip (NY)
results.title: Fetty Wap Is Sentenced to 6 Years in Prison for Running Drugs
results.abstract: Prosecutors said the rapper, best known for his hit “Trap Queen,” glamorized drugs — and sold them even as he made millions from his music.

media.caption: Prosecutors said Fetty Wap sang about the drug trade even as he participated in it.

results.title: How Scorsese, DiCaprio and De Niro Made ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’
results.abstract: In this true-life crime tale, they focused not on the investigators but on the evildoers, and made the Osage woman played by Lily Gladstone central.

media.caption: Robert De Niro and Leonardo DiCaprio in “Killers of the Flower Moon.”

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Pop and Rock Music;Rhythm and Blues (Music);internal-sub-only;internal-open-access-search;Turner, Tina;Turner, Ike
results.title: Tina Turner, Magnetic Singer of Explosive Power, Is Dead at 83
results.abstract: Hailed in the 1960s for her dynamic performances with her first husband, Ike, she became a sensation as a recording artist, often echoing her personal struggles in her songs.

media.caption: Tina Turner in concert in Los Angeles in 1984. Her album “Private Dancer,” released that year, returned her to the spotlight after a long absence and lifted her into the pop stratosphere.

results.byline: By Catie Edmondson and Luke Broadwater
results.title: McCarthy, Bracing for Defections, Eyes a Fraught Path to a Debt Limit Deal
results.abstract: With right-wing Republicans all but certain to oppose any bipartisan compromise, the speaker has a narrow path to push one through the closely divided House.

media.caption: Speaker Kevin McCarthy and President Biden will need to make compromises in order to reach a deal on the debt ceiling.

results.title: In Shaky Start, Ron DeSantis Joins 2024 Race, Hoping to Topple Trump
results.abstract: The Florida governor, Donald Trump’s strongest challenger since 2016, made an unusual and glitch-marred entrance on Twitter alongside Elon Musk. He now faces a daunting clash with Mr. Trump and his scorched-earth tactics.

media.caption: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida will seek to turn the Republican primary race into a two-man contest against former President Donald J. Trump.

results.title: Surgeon General Warns That Social Media May Harm Children and Adolescents
results.abstract: The report by Dr. Vivek Murthy cited a “profound risk of harm” to adolescent mental health and urged families to set limits and governments to set tougher standards for use.
